Long story short: Great game, meets my high expectations.

35463782.review:
It's traditional Picross (Nonogram) puzzles. If you aren't a fan of Picross, or don't know what it is, you probably don't want this. Just getting that out of the way.

If you [i]are[/i] a fan of Picross puzzles, this is [b]the[/b] genre title for your library.

It's got hundreds of puzzles - to which any seasoned Picross veteran scoffs and says "Yeah, but how many [i]hard[/i] ones does it have?"

Loads. I mean it. This game, compared to other collections of Picross puzzles, is [i]freakin' hard[/i]. The demo is free, and it has mostly easy puzzles - but don't let that disappoint you. They blow through the easy ones in the demo so that when you buy the game, you're [i]satisfied[/i]. Those tutorial collections are a joke - the entire paid game ahead is a series of collections of themed puzzles, that get progressively harder (both within each collection, and as you advance). By the time you are a third of the way through, you'll forget what a "small" puzzle looks like. Prepare yourself for [i]many[/i] 30x30 or larger puzzles.

To make things more fun, the Picross gets colorized in the miniature form to depict a pixel art rather than a traditional black-and-white result. This gimmick is common in the genre, and really helps enhance the game experience (as well as provide more leverage in puzzle design) - but Paint It Back really takes the bull by the horns and builds a bit of a storyline around the concept, where you are tasked with "re-painting" the contents of artwork that has been scared white by a ghost. The art is well done (for what you can cram into a pixel art, at least) and the actual puzzles are well matched to their colorized results.

There is also the Mystery Masterpiece challenge, which is basically a random Picross from the collection, [i]without the colorized miniature or hint title[/i]. You're flying blind, but you're solving one you may have already done. There are enough puzzles to confuse your memory, just don't fall back on this mode a lot and you'll be fine. Besides, as if there aren't enough provided puzzles...

Then, there is [i]also[/i] the Workshop support, where people can build, share, play, and rate puzzles (and their associated "artwork") through the game. I had a browse, and it looks like you won't run out of Picross until this game runs out of people submitting them.

Long and short: The business, if you love Picross.

There have been tons of nonogram games since Picross (and the puzzle itself has existed even longer), so I wrote this one off at first, especially since there are free alternatives on mobile and such. But, this is one of my favorite kinds of puzzle, so I picked Paint it Back up on sale. I was surprised!

The game hits all the things I'd want for this sort of puzzle:
Lots of puzzles, all well designed, not too many tutorial puzzles
Adjustable difficulty (even early on some of the master puzzles were really challenging!)
Colorful and funny (punny) images
Smooth mouse controls for speed painting (though it would be nice if undo had a hotkey)
A puzzle maker with Workshop support
And though I haven't unlocked it yet, what appear to be extra modes including timed modes.

I'd have to nitpick to find anything wrong with it. The music is nice but there isn't enough of it to keep it from becoming repetitive really early on, and though it's unnecessary and probably hard to develop, I miss the animated solutions from the Picross DS days. That's about it!

Basically, if you like this sort of puzzle, this is well worth the money. If you've never tried it, the demo is more than enough to find out if you like it.

A very good Picross-style game.  There are A LOT of puzzles, which is definitely a good thing.  I don't love that many of the puzzles have dimensions that are not multiples of 5 (ie, 8 x 16), but the flexibility in dimensions also allows for a great variety of puzzles.  Another difference that Picross fans might find unsettling is that the game doesn't penalize you for making a wrong move.  This makes it possible to screw up a puzzle to the point where you have to start over.  I kind of like this because the game doesn't give you any clues, so to speak, but it also can be frustrating when you have to restart a puzzle that you've spent 20 minutes on already.  There might be an option to change this, but I didn't look real hard for it.

This game does have a nice set of options and modes, which make it much more robust than your typical Picross-clone.  I haven't messed with much of that stuff, but it just goes to show you that these developers really tried.  If you like Picross, this is probably your best option on Steam.

31451220.review:
Paint it Back é um jogo de puzzle lógico, baseado no conceito conhecido como Nonogram ou Picross. Aqui no Brasil ficou conhecido como Pic-a-Pix, graças a revista "Logic Pix" de passatempos da Coquetel, infelizmente descontinuada. Foi por este meio inclusive que conheci e me viciei neste tipo de puzzle.

No jogo você é um artista ajudando a reconstruir uma galeria de arte que misteriosamente perdeu toda a tinta de suas telas. Esse é apenas um pano de fundo para justificar tantos puzzles a serem resolvidos. Todo o jogo segue este conceito de galeria de arte, cada puzzle sendo um quadro, agrupados em séries conceituais (mostras), cada sala com seu artista.

A arte do jogo é simples, mas que casa muito bem com o senso de humor leve e quase infantil das obras. Os quadros, na sua maioria brincam com situações inusitadas, reveses e paradigmas, além de satirizar algumas obras reais.

A música é agradável mas infelizmente enjoativa, considerando que você irá passar longas horas jogando para poder completar a galeria inteira e a trilha deve contar com umas 4 músicas que se repetem aleatóriamente (muitas vezes a mesma musica se repete na sequência).

O conceito do puzzle basicamente é, com a ajuda das dicas (sequências de números) apresentadas nas margens esquerda e superior da grade, construir um desenho. Por mais que possa parecer fácil, você irá mudar de ideia rapidamente assim que tentar resolver seu primeiro problema. Similar ao Sudoku, este é um puzzle que conta com diversas técnicas; técnicas estas que você irá se dar conta de estar descobrindo e aprendendo naturalmente. Isso porque o jogo, com sua dificuldade progressiva, irá fazer você compreender aos poucos como os números se relacionam. Pelo bem de sua experiência, não procure na internet sobre técnicas de Nonogram ou muito menos como resolver os puzzles do jogo.

O jogo tem mais de 150 puzzles, que podem ser resolvidos em três dificuldades "Normal", "Pro" e "Master". No Master, a grade é sempre apresentada em sua íntegra, podendo chegar até a 40 colunas ou linhas. No modo Normal e Pro, dependendo da dimensão do puzzle, o mesmo é dividido em sessões menores, facilitando sua construção. Além disso o jogo conta com a "mãozinha amiga" que indica imediatamente um erro no desenho; jogar com esta opção ativa não marca a pintura como restaurada.

Caso isso tudo não seja suficiente ou você queira testar suas habilidades em um modo um pouco mais desafiador, a sala Mystery Masterpiece é a opção. Um puzzle é escolhido aleatoriamente para ser resolvido e não é apresentada uma prévia do resultado. Neste modo você é condecorado com medalhas dependendo da dificuldade, do tempo, da quantidade de erros e da quantidade de marcações de apoio utilizadas.

Se ainda assim você ainda tem sede de puzzles, o jogo tem suporte ao Workshop, onde você pode baixar puzzles criados pela comunidade e desenvolver os seus próprios.

O jogo surpreendentemente ainda conta com suporte a controles; então, caso você se sinta mais confortável em jogar com um controle do que com um mouse, vá em frente!

Paint it Back é um jogo que vale muito a pena jogar, muito bem trabalhado, com muito conteúdo e feito com carinho para quem gosta de puzzles lógicos e principalmente para quem gosta de colocar o cérebro pra funcionar.

É com muita satisfação, sensação de dever cumprido e uma pontada de saudades que, após finalizar o jogo em sua íntegra, obter todos os achievements e deixar esta análise como um agradecimento de despedida, desinstalo o jogo. Até uma próxima! Recomendadíssimo!

30905959.review:
[i][b]Paint it Back[/b][/i] est un très bon jeu de réflexion de type [i]Picross[/i], une variante du démineur dans laquelle les nombres ne sont pas placés à l'intérieur de la grille, mais sur ses bords. Ici, il s'agit donc d'en noircir les cases en tenant compte des nombreuses indications, qui nous sont toutes données dès le début. Le concept est à la fois simple et efficace, même s'il peut paraître un poil répétitif pour qui enchaîne de longues sessions de jeu.

A côté de la plupart des lignes et colonnes est donc inscrite une série de valeurs. Si tel n'est pas le cas, considérez qu'aucune case de la rangée n'a besoin d'être noircie. Par exemple, l'indication 2-1-4 à gauche d'une ligne de 10 cases signifie qu'elle contient au total 7 cases noires, réparties en trois groupes (respectivement, de 2, 1, puis 4 cases), chaque groupe étant séparé du suivant par une ou plusieurs cases vides. Les solutions peuvent alors être multiples. Ici, il en existe quatre. Mais, que ce soit clair, [i][b]Paint it Back[/b][/i] fait la part belle au raisonnement logique : jamais vous n'aurez à vous en remettre au hasard ! Toute l'astuce consiste à mettre en corrélation les informations verticales et horizontales.

Chaque niveau correspond à un tableau accompagné d'une légende le plus souvent obscure, a posteriori pleine d'humour, qui prend par ailleurs tout son sens une fois la toile reconstituée. Selon sa taille vous seront proposés de un à trois modes de difficulté : normal, pro ou master. Ils vous permettront, si toutefois vous vous retrouviez bloqué, de scinder le puzzle en plusieurs étapes plus abordables. A ces 150 tableaux répartis sur quinze galeries s'ajoute un mode de jeu supplémentaire, qui consiste à atteindre divers objectifs : finir le plus vite possible, avec un minimum d'encre (c.à.d. sans se tromper quand on noircit les cases) ou de croix, nécessaires pour marquer celles dont on a déduit qu'elles étaient vides.

Tout ceci pour dire que [i][b]Paint it Back[/b][/i] dispose d'un contenu tout bonnement gargantuesque ! La preuve, plus de quarante heures de jeu ne m'auront pas suffi pour terminer tous les tableaux en master. En conclusion, un très bon jeu de réflexion, qui s'apprécie d'autant plus en petites sessions, au risque sinon de le trouver répétitif.

29519263.review:
[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O4irXQhgMqg]Paint it Black[/url] je parádní písnička od skupiny Rolling Stones. Patří mezi mé nejoblíbenější od nich a... no... tahle hra se ale jmenuje Paint it Back...

[h1]Namaluj to zpátky[/h1]
Název hry vtipně odkazuje právě na onu písničku, což byl jeden z důvodů, proč mě hra zaujala. Paint it Back patří mezi logické tituly. Jedná se o tzv. picross, u nás spíše známé jako malovaná křížovka, případně zakódované obrázky. Máte plochu rozdělenou na čtverečky a na levé straně a nahoře se nachází čísla. Ta určují, kolik čtverečků bude zabarveno na černo. Pokud tedy máte u prvního řádku číslo deset a je tam deset čtverečků, budou všechny zabarveny. Pokud však bude číslo jen jednička, bude pouze jeden černý a zbytek zůstane bílých.

Aby to bylo komplikovanější, na bocích máte velmi často vícero čísel. Mezi těmito čísly musí být vždy minimálně jedno prázdné políčko. Pokud někdo tenhle popis nechápe, dávám sem odkaz na [url=https://cs.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malovan%C3%A1_k%C5%99%C3%AD%C5%BEovka]wikipedii[/url], kde to máte i hezky graficky znázorněno. Nemusíte se ale bát, princip hry je opravdu jednoduchý.

[h1]Pojďme opravit všechny obrazy[/h1]
Hra nabízí dokonce i příběh, ale nečekejte žádné zvraty nebo něco speciálního. Jste majitelem galerie a všechny vaše obrazy se znenadání smazaly. Vaším úkolem je je přemalovat a postupně tak otevřít veřejnosti všechny části vaší budovy. Hádanky jsou tedy formovány do jednotlivých tématických částí, které se vám postupně odemykají a vy tak můžete i vybírat, na jakou se vrhnete dříve.

Navíc se liší i velikost hádanek, tudíž začínáte od těch menších (rozměry 5x5), až se dostanete k obludnostech o rozměrech i přes 30x40. Naštěstí potěší volba obtížnosti hry. U většiny hádanek si totiž můžete vybrat, jak moc těžkou ji chcete mít. Máte tu tedy obtížnosti Normal, Pro a Master. A jak to funguje? Pokud vyberete hádanku, která má hodně políček, můžete si ji nechat rozdělit na menší části, u kterých už přece jen nebudete tak moc tápat. Takže místo 30x12 budete mít třikrát 10x12.

Čím těžší hádanka, tím více stuh získáte. Příjemné je, že tu máte opravdu hromadu levelů, jejichž dokončení na maximální počet stuh vám zabere několik desítek, ne-li stovek hodin. Poté tu naleznete ještě speciální generátor levelů, kde řešíte hádanky na čas a získáváte další speciální stuhy. U tohoto módu je obrovská nevýhoda v tom, že nenabízí nové hádanky, ale pouze ty, které se nachází v základní hře.

[h1]Malířem snadno a rychle[/h1]
Rozhraní hry je přehledné, minimalistické. To stejné platí i o ovládání, kdy využijete pouze myš. Levým tlačítkem označíte políčko jako černé, pravým zase umístíte křížek, což značí, že toto políčko je prázdné. Opětovným kliknutím smažete dané políčko, takže zde žádné záludnosti nehledejte.

Grafická stylizace je dobrá. Co mi ale vadilo, byla hudba. Opakují se tu snad jen tři krátké skladby a velmi brzy vám začnou lézt na nervy. No a poté jsem měl problémy i se samotnou hrou. Je tu jedna věc, která ji shazuje. Ukládání. Snad každého napadne, že u obrovských hádanek strávíte hromadu času, zvlášť, když je budete řešit na nejtěžší obtížnost. Systém ukládání funguje tak, že vám danou hádanku uloží a vy se k jejímu řešení můžete kdykoliv vrátit. V čem je tedy háček? Nevýhodou je právě onen počet uložení. V jeden okamžik totiž můžete mít uložený postup pouze v jedné jediné hádance. Někomu to může stačit, ale krása téhle hry právě spočívá v tom, že máte volný přístup k většině obsahu. Začnete řešit jednu hádanku, je ale těžší, uložíte ji a jdete na druhou, která se ale ukáže také jako těžká, jenže už tam máte více jak polovinu vyřešeno a musíte třeba najednou odejít. A co teď? Uložit tuhle nebo nechat jako uloženou tu první? Je to neuvěřitelná škoda, že tu je tenhle nedostatek.

No a poté mám ještě jednu výtku, která je spíše osobní. Hra je jednotvárná. Je neustále o tom samém, jen se postupně zvětšuje herní plocha. Někomu tohle může vyhovovat a chápu, že pokud chcete hru s tímto stylem hádanek, budete chrochtat blahem. Jenže já tak nějak doufal, že se postupně přidají další prvky, které ozvláštní tento titul.

Na závěr dodám, že tu je podpora workshopu, takže si můžete stáhnout díla od jiných uživatelů Steamu nebo zkusit vytvořit vlastní.

[h1]Plusy[/h1]
+ jednoduchá hratelnost
+ hromada hádanek
+ výběr obtížnosti
+ grafická stylizace
+ minimalistické rozhraní
+ podpora workshopu

[h1]Mínusy[/h1]
- uloží se pouze jedna hádanka
- hudba
- hra je stále o tom stejném

[h1]Konečný verdikt[/h1]
[b]Mé hodnocení: 7/10[/b]

Paint it Back je rozhodně nadprůměrná hra, která vydrží na několik desítek hodin. Pokud jste milovníci malovaných křížovek, momentálně neseženete na Steamu nic lepšího.

25267452.review:
Semplice e immediato, soprattutto per i primi livelli che scorrono via con una semplicità disarmante (probabilmente vista anche la mia esperienza con questo genere di giochi), il gioco di Casual Labs comincia a porre delle sfide interessanti con una curva d’apprendimento davvero intelligente: all’aumentare della grandezza della griglia, potremo decidere se affrontare il puzzle nella sua versione completa o se invece provare a risolverlo sezione per sezione. Chiaramente, per ottenere tutte le coccarde dovremo completare i quadri al livello di difficoltà maggiore (il quale sblocca tutte le coccarde precedenti), buttandoci a capofitto in disegni da 30×30, 40×40 e così via. Una scelta che ho davvero apprezzato, sia perché così il mio spirito masochista può essere facilmente accontentato da disegni giganteschi, sia perché anche i nuovi giocatori possono godersi il titolo e portarlo al compimento senza per forza perdere anche un’ora intera su un dipinto.

Molto carino anche l’incipit con il quale dovremo ricolorare i quadri: un fantasmino si è introdotto in una galleria e ha spaventato i soggetti dipinti. Da bravo schiavetto del pittore baffuto di turno sarà nostro compito riportare l’ordine e riaprire le ali della mostra dedicata all’artista. Nulla di che, sia chiaro, ma questo piccolo spunto è servito a caratterizzare tutta la grafica del gioco e gli stessi disegni che dovremo “ricolorare” (da qui il titolo), essendo questi divisi per argomento. Non preoccupatevi per la qualità dei primi: dopo anni di Picross capisco quanto possa essere difficile trovare nuove figure semplici, ma con l’apertura delle nuove ali della museo, cominceremo ad avere a che fare con quadri molto più complessi e sicuramente molto più piacevoli da ammirare una volta completati. Sempre in stile 8 bit sia chiaro.

I initially reviewed Paint It Back as a demo and at the time, I gave it a "thumbs down." After playing the actual game and making a real effort to learn it, I've decided my original assessment was flawed.

PIB is a very complex and not easily understood puzzle game. It requires you to push yourself to learn the game, as opposed to most games (puzzle or otherwise) where figuring out how to play is often very quick and easy.

I'll admit, the learning curve is an obstacle and not one every gamer will wish to tackle. I know I certainly didn't when I reviewed the demo. That said, if you stick with it, you'll be pleasantly surprised. 

The basic game mechanics are simple: there are numbers on the left and on the top. Those numbers denote how many squares need to be colored in. If there's more than one number on any line, it means there's a space between those two numbers.

Where this game goes from simple to complex is that unless the number listed corresponds to ALL spaces in any column or row, you won't immediately know where to place a mark. Even more challenging is knowing how many spaces are between multiple numbers.

Now add in paintings that can be huge (especially on harder difficulty levels) and you've got yourself a very daunting task. 

Fortunately, there is usually some clue somewhere to help you begin and to work off of. What may throw new players is that these clues aren't very recognizable unless you've played this game for a while or similar titles elsewhere. 

So would I recommend Paint It Black? Yes, but do make sure to check out the demo first and try to be in the right mindset to take on a challenging game like this. Don't expect to figure it all out quickly, because that'll just lead to frustration. Take your time and learn it as you go and eventually (likely sooner than later) you'll have that "aha!" moment where it all makes sense and the game becomes far more enjoyable.

23890850.review:
If you both know what nonograms are and enjoy them, just stop reading this review and buy the game.

If you're not familiar with the word, a nonogram is a puzzle similar in spirit to sudoku and other logic puzzles of that sort, except it's pictographic. You fill in (or cross out) spaces in a pixel grid following a simple set of logic rules, and with that information, you fill in more spaces, etc. If your logic is impeccable every step of the way, you have a picture when you're done. If not, well, you'll probably have to start over. :) They're a lot of fun, and serve as a great way to relax and unwind will still engaging your mind.

Paint it Back (I find it almost impossible not to type/say Paint it Black) is an almost perfect implementation of nonograms. There are a lot of puzzles included, at a variety of skill levels, and you can play the harder puzzles at easier skill levels if you prefer, which breaks them down into sub-puzzles for you. There are hinting modes if you need them, the controls are easy to learn and provide both keyboard and mouse-based control, the graphics are good, and the puzzle themes are funny. They've also recently included support for playing puzzles created by other users in the Steam community. Also, if you have a shared family PC, the game supports up to six player accounts so that everybody in the family can play without messing up each other's save games. (I'm not sure how critical this is if you have separate accounts anyway, though.)

If I have any complaints, they're very minor. There were a small number of puzzles that could only be completed with guess-work, and some may enjoy that (or at least not mind it), but I dislike these. There's a whole user interface element which could be implemented slightly better called "Marks" to support this sort of guessing. Given that only 2-3 of the puzzles included required it, I feel like they could have left Marks out entirely and swapped in puzzles that didn't require any guessing and the game would have been improved. Also, at least on my system, the keyboard controls were prone to occasionally repeating when you tapped a key, which made using the cursor to count a bit tricky at times. I would have preferred a delay-before-repeat on the keyboard controls to prevent this. 

This is one of my few Perfect Steam games, because the achievements were actually fun enough to go for even when they required additional play after I'd completed all the puzzles.

Overall, if you like this sort of game, or you think you might, I'd say go for it.

This is a solid picross game that doesn't stray much from the standard formula, but it doesn't need to.

There's a large number of puzzles available, probably at least 30 hours' worth of "official" ones in the game without even getting into the ones available from the Steam Workshop. The picture themes are amusing and bizarre, and some of the harder ones are quite large, with dimensions like 40x30. For people that don't want something quite that difficult, you also have the option of splitting the larger puzzles into "sections" so that you work on multiple smaller puzzles that all combine into the overall image in the end.

It plays well using any one of a mouse, keyboard, or gamepad, and the controls are customizable if needed. The interface has a few other nice aspects as well, including a "mark mode" where you can test some guesses out in a different color (necessary for a couple of the hardest puzzles).

Definitely recommended if you enjoy logic puzzles (and picross games in particular). Excellent value, even at full price.

22023810.review:
В последней книге про Нарнию Клайва Льюиса рассказывается о том, что некоторые гномы, одурманенные или неготовые, не могли увидеть мир, каким его видели главные герои, и понять его ценности. То же самое было в другой замечательной книге этого же автора «Пока мы лиц не обрели»: сестра Психеи не видела замок Амура, не понимала радость Психеи. И в общем, мне кажется, Paint it Back для одних людей – примитивная головоломка. А для любителей японских кроссвордов – просто чудо и исполнение заветной мечты!
На первый взгляд, игра так проста, что ее стоит размещать не в Стиме, а на каком-нибудь сайте простеньких игр, к которым обращаются скучающие офисные работники, если у них заблокированы социальные сети. Но на самом деле в ней гениальный минимализм сочетается с разнообразием кроссвордов и их настроек. Сначала идут совсем простенькие кроссворды, видимо, для постигающих азы. Но через некоторое время появятся загадки, над которыми придется поломать голову, особенно если поставить уровень сложности «мастер». 
А самое главное, в эту игру комфортно играть. Даже в подобных приложениях не всегда игроку бывает так удобно, не говоря уже о том, что в реальности приходится разгадывать иные японские кроссворды с линейкой, стеркой и скрежетом зубов. А тут ряды целиком выделяются курсором, цифры, отображающие закрашенные клетки, темнеют. Два простых инструмента - кисть для закрашивания и для пометок крестиками пустых клеток – то, что нужно, не больше, не меньше. Если вы ошибетесь в одном месте, вам не придется разрывать лист кроссворда пополам и швырять в стенку. Не придется начинать все сначала. Вы можете попробовать разгадывать из другого угла и в результате заметить ошибку. Конечно, в реальности тоже можно так делать, но на листе останутся следы. А в игре все можно исправить быстро, удобно и незаметно. 
Через меню можно отменять действия. А если выходите из игры, можно сохранить прогресс. Рядом на мольберте вы можете увидеть, какой рисунок у вас получается в процессе. Только нельзя сказать, что это является подсказкой. Закрашенные клетки только в финале похожи на картину. До этого пытаться угадать, что там нарисовано - это по большей части все равно, что в расположении звезд на небе пытаться увидеть именно фигуры созвездий. Зато названия «шедевров искусства» явно созданы с юмором и иронией. Например, «Муравей, нахлобучивший шляпу» или «Совет: не здоровайтесь с белым медведем за руку». Не менее интересно бывает потыкать курсором в колоритных персонажей, не то посетителей выставки, не то [strike]галлюцинаций художника[/strike] экспонатов. Они стоят в начале каждой галереи и иногда что-то делают и произносят. Вот только  удивительно, почему по сюжету картины исчезли, испугавшись привидения? По идее один вид гигантского муравья с пачками долларов должен был ужаснуть и отпугнуть их.
Если вы знаете, как разгадывать японские кроссворды, русификатор вам не понадобится. А вот звук в игре вообще лучше отключить, пока этот навязчивый мотив не начал снится в кошмарах. Вместо этого лучше параллельно запустить на планшете или телефоне какую-то любимую музыку. И тогда хорошее времяпрепровождение гарантировано. 
Напоследок хочется отметить, что эта простенькая игра в определенном смысле превзошла и Fallout-4, и Ведьмака и множество других модных, дорогих и масштабных игр. Ведь у Fallout и подобных игр встречаются отрицательные обзоры.  У Paint it Back на момент написания этого обзора нет ни одного отрицательного отзыва!

[h1]Le temps d'un café[/h1]

Un très bon jeu de picross. Le seul en fait sur steam (màj 2017 : ce n'est plus le cas, il a maintenant des concurrents)

Si vous ne connaissez pas le principe, vous disposez d'une grille avec des numéros sur les côtés. Chaque numéro représente un nombre de cases à griser sur une ligne ou une colonne. Chaque groupe de chiffres ne peut en toucher un autre. Par exemple s'il est écrit 2-3-2, vous devrez placer : ☐☐☒☐☐☐☒☐☐ Bien sûr, ça doit coller entre l'horizontal et la verticale. Le résultat des cases grisées représente une image sur un thème donné.

La particularité de cette adaptation, c'est d'être présentée sous forme d'une gallerie de tableaux. Tous regroupés par thème : la nature, les animaux, etc. Avec des images et des titres amusants. Une fois passé le tuto, chaque tableau est dispo en deux ou trois niveaux de difficulté rapportant plus ou moins d'étoiles, et débloquant peu à peu les thèmes suivants. Une grille plus grande rend la résolution plus complexe.

[h1]En bref[/h1]

+ Sympa l'idée de la gallerie de tableaux.
+ Contenu varié et amusant.
+ Trois niveaux de difficulté.
+ Il y en a pour des heures vu le nombre de tableaux. Une màj a ajouté le workshop si vous en en voulez encore plus !
+ Entièrement jouable à la souris.
= Pas de workshop pour le moment, mais le dev parle de peut-être en ajouter un avec éditeur.
- L'image du tableau fini en haut à gauche est un peu petite.
- La musique est le clairement le gros point faible. Ultra-répétitive, autant la couper.

20959225.review:
Definitely recommend this game to people who enjoy puzzle games (and/or art). The tutorial is LITERALLY amazing. It is hands down the best tutorial in a game ever. of all time. best tutorial ever. Now I came into this game already knowing how to play this type of puzzle game, so I rushed through the tutorial, but for a new player to this type of a puzzle game if they went through the tutorial all the information they need would be in that tutorial. Not only is it jam packed with several techniques and building blocks for other ones, it is very clear and precise. It also has a system to make sure you understand (which I'm very keen of). 

After playing the tutorial I zoomed by the first gallery and I was sad that this game wouldn't be challenging because the puzzles were so easy (I'm an experienced player so the normal puzzles didnt teach me anything), but once I hit a Pro picture I was like dammmmmmm gurl nice. and then when I hit a Master picture I was like YES BOYS. And while the difficulty spike in my opinion shoots almost straight up, its very very fun. I have only played a few galleries, but I'm presuming the difficulty won't be going down, so I'm sure all of the galleries are really good! For the asking price and the content of this game, and the tutorial. I'd say this is a must buy steam game for puzzle genre lovers. I've even recommended it to friends because I feel like the tutorial is so good even noobs could start playing this game and end up a 'Master' level player. 

The story line is brief, and the characters at the beginning of each gallery are commical for those who know art. I haven't gone past like the fourth or fifth gallery but I was a bit sad to see that you dont actually do the color part of the painting like instead of a row being 5 in a 5x5 board it could be 1121 and each number representing a different color. That would take away from the difficulty but I think it'd be really cool and I hope that I find it later on in the game. If it doesn't show up that's fine the game will still be amazing.  The UI (menu and the board itself) still needs some work to be 5/5, and I'm not the best judge for music, it's fairly good background music for this game(although one of the tracks, not sure which one, has a misleading sound in it aka a sound from another program that notifies sometime, although it's not that prominent). 

Overall I'd give this game like a 4.8/5. I wanna give it the five but 5/5 is perfect and realistically the UI is not perfect so it'd be injust if I did so. Highly recommend this game!

Thanks to the developer(s) and everyone else involved for creating this! Definitely one of the best puzzle games I've played on steam. (:s the niche genre markets on steam are really weak.)

20800901.review:
[i]TL;DR: [b]Paint it Back[/b] is a pleasant and fairly challenging collection of nonograms with some nice and curious pixel art.[/i]

When I bought it I didn't expect [i]Paint it Back[/i] to last over 40 hours but it did anyway. After all at its core it is just a (fairly large) collection of [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonogram]nonograms[/url], also known as grittlers or hanjies.

In case you don't know them, in nonograms you are given a grid of boxes and a set of numbers at the edge. The numbers determine how many adjacent boxes are "filled" in each row or column. In these puzzles the solution usually is designed to form a recognizable picture. All puzzles in the game have exactly one solution.

[h1]Smooth and casual gameplay[/h1]

There is a flimsy (but working) back story to motivate using nonograms: a ghost has scared away all the paintings in a gallery. You are tasked to "paint" it all back.

The gallery has over dozen sections with separate themes each with circa ten puzzles of increasing difficulty per section. The puzzles are tiered in 3 difficulty settings pertaining to the size of the grid, from 5x5 (normal) to 40x30 (master).

Mouse controls work splendidly: left-click "paints", right-click marks a box empty and both marks can be reversed by clicking again. There's also a test mark-up mode that one can use to try out and find conflicts when regular logic fails (essentially required in only a couple of the master-level paintings). A neat detail is that the color picture slowly forms in the corner while you are "painting".

The art is generally good and quirky and every painting is a small surprise, so it's fun to solve the problems.

[h1]Perfect for what it is[/h1]

When playing I like to alt+tab every now and then for small pauses. I was happy to note this didn't have any adverse effects on the game. Being a mobile port, there is the slightly redundant (considering Steam Family share) option to create up to 6 profiles for e.g. all family members. Despite this you can unfortunately have only one incomplete painting saved at the time (per profile I presume) although you can work on others, just without saving the progress if you wanted to quit.

For 100% achievement completion it took me almost 42 hours. I think that's a great amount of content for a game such as this. There's some repetition required for achievement hunters, since about half of the medals (conveniently displayed also in-game) are about the random challenges that require you to complete a random existing painting in a specific way (including quickly, without empty-crosses and/or without "wasting paint"). Still, this adds only couple of hours to the whole gametime. The more difficult puzzles can be completed on lower difficulty levels as well (by solving them part-wise as several smaller nonograms) that might add even more content for completionists though it is not required for the achievements.

However, it is just a collection of nonograms with no twists except perhaps for the quirky art. I got it for half the price and I was happy with the content but I might have been disappointed had I paid the full price. Unless you really [i]love[/i] nonograms you should also wait for a sale.

20761880.review:
[h1][i]“Paint it Back”[/i] is an ABSOLUTELY FANTASTIC puzzle game with lots of humor.[/h1]

All the paintings from a gallery have vanished, and now you should help to recreate them! 
When you try to recreate a painting for the first time, you have no idea what it looks like – it only has a title and a nonogram (that grid of squares, sudoku style) with "instructions" for you to paint the image bit by bit. But even after the image has been revealed, it is still a (nice) challenge to do the process of completing it. 

Small paintings can be completed on normal mode and larger ones can also be completed on harder modes (professional and master). There are 150 different paintings which, considering all their available difficulty modes, add up to 329 puzzles!

After completing all the paintings at least once (at least on their easiest difficulty) a "random" game mode is unlocked, on which you can simply choose a difficulty level and get a random painting to complete. This mode will award you medals according to your performance (completing the painting within a time limit, not making many mistakes, not marking the empty spaces, etc).

In addition to being a very smart puzzle, another important part of [i]“Paint it Back”[/i] is it’s humor, ranging from parodies of famous paintings to images and titles quite... unusual... [spoiler][url=www.steamcommunity.com/id/dwolfy666/screenshot/355024597596116238]*example*[/url][/spoiler]

[b]In short, [i]“Paint it Back”[/i] is extremely fun, has great replay value and yields many and many hours of fun![/b]


[quote][b][i]* PORTUGUÊS *[/i][/b][/quote]

[h1][i]“Paint it Back[/i] é um puzzle ABSOLUTAMENTE FANTÁSTICO e com muito humor.[/h1]

Todas as obras de arte de uma galeria sumiram, e agora você deve ajudar a recriá-las! Na primeira vez que vai recriar um quadro, você não tem ideia de como ele é - ele tem apenas um título e um nonograma (aquela grade de quadradinhos, estilo sudoku) com "instruções" para que você vá montando a imagem pouco a pouco. Mas mesmo depois de a imagem ter sido revelada ainda é um (bom) desafio completá-la. 

Quadros pequenos podem ser completados no modo normal e quadros maiores podem ser completados também em níveis mais difíceis (profissional e mestre). São 150 quadros diferentes, que, considerando todos os seus modos de dificuldade disponíveis, somam 329 quebra-cabeças! 

Depois de completar todos os quadros pelo menos uma vez (ao menos na dificuldade mais fácil) é liberado um modo de jogo "randômico", onde você simplesmente escolhe o nível de dificuldade e recebe um quadro aleatório para completar. Esse modo te dá medalhas de acordo com seu desempenho (terminar dentro do limite de tempo, não cometer muitos erros, não marcar os espaços vazios, etc). 

Além de ser um puzzle muito inteligente, outra grande parte importante de [i]“Paint it Back”[/i] é seu humor, que vai desde paródias de quadros famosos até imagens e títulos bastante... incomuns... [spoiler][url=www.steamcommunity.com/id/dwolfy666/screenshot/355024597596116238]*exemplo*[/url][/spoiler]

[b]Em resumo, [i]“Paint it Back”[/i]  é extremamente divertido, tem ótima rejogabilidade e rende muitas e muitas horas de diversão![/b]

19181308.review:
This is a good nonogram puzzle game.

It has 150+ black and white nonograms, but the picture they encode are in color (upper left on the screenshots), so the shapes are not always obvious. Sizes range from 5x5 to 40x30. For the larger sizes, there are options to break them up into smaller parts to make them easier to solve, but you get less rewards. There are also rewards for not using X marks, for not making mistakes, and for being fast. Because there's a challenge mode where it will select a random puzzle of the whole set for you to do without telling you which one it is, there is limited replayability. The interface is ok.

If you like these types of puzzles, you can confidently buy this game. (There's a demo, too.)

19150084.review: It's Picross, presented in a clean, easy-to-work-with interface. Left click fills a box, right click marks it as empty. You can also switch left click back-and-forth between the two, which you might inadvertently do if you use the Steam overlay. The early puzzles may be easy, but the game gets tough quickly - there's easily your money's worth here in sheer hours-per-dollar, even more if you're as bad at Picross as me. As an added bonus, some of the jokes are funny.

19075531.review:
Very nice game for everyone who loves Picross or wants to try it for the first time. There are a variety of paintings and difficulties, and even the biggest paintings (30x40 or 40x30 respectively) can be played on the lowest difficulty if wished. Also, the motives of the paintings are hilarious at times.
Additionally, when playing for a bit you will soon unlock the "Mystery Masterpieces", which is basically a random mode that's fun even when you already finished all pictures of the gallery.

For people like me who prefer playing on the highest difficulty (which means you have to puzzle through the whole picture at once, for otherwise the pictures are broken into multiple smaller parts) it certainly is challenging enough - although there were two or three pictures that could not be solved with pure logic and needed the Mark-up mode (which means guessing, something I personally really don't like to do when puzzling).
Still, besides that one I think the difficulty and logic for this game fit perfectly.

The only thing I really disliked was the fact that the numbers on the side / at the top already turned grey the second the correct number of black spots was there on the field (as long as it had a direkt connection with blacks and Xs to one of the sides). I usually play Nintendo's Picross games and there they only grey out the numbers when the black spots have an X (or the end of the picture) on [i]both sides[/i].
So I would really have preferred an option to either manage it like that or to maybe grey the numbers out manually. That would mean more work for me but as I prefer having 'perfect' scores (as in, no wrongly set black spots ever if possible) this turned out to be really annoying during the mystery masterpiece runs.

But that's a really minor complain for I still had a lot of fun with this game and I will certainly play it again, for the random mode is fun even if you already have all the achievements.
Definitely a very good Picross game - and the best version of it I have encountered on the PC as of yet!

18867998.review:
Puzzle Lovers delight!  

In the past I've only tried this type of puzzle on paper in puzzle books, but did not get very far with them because of having to erase mistakes, but there would still be some shading left from where I erased and it got confusing.  But with this game I can paint and erase with the flick of a mouse.  Much easier.

For those who have never encountered this type of puzzle before I'm gonna quote from wikipedia:

"Nonograms, also known as Hanjie, Picross or Griddlers, are picture logic puzzles in which cells in a grid must be colored or left blank according to numbers at the side of the grid to reveal a hidden picture."

It's kind of like a binary sudoku.  If you love logic puzzles, you will like this.  I quickly got addicted.

How does it work:
You've got a grid of squares and you are told how many spaces are supposed to be colored in on each row and column.  Use logic to choose what to color in.  When you are finished it forms a picture.  You only use black and white, but there is a colored painting that appears as you work on the puzzle.  You don't actually have to choose colors yourself, it does it automatically.

Difficulty Settings:
There are 3 difficulty levels.  The beginning puzzles are only on the easiest difficulty, but as you progress in later galleries you can choose which difficulty level you want for each painting.  And even after you finish a puzzle you can redo it on another difficulty level.   

The puzzles also come in different sizes.  From 10x10 to 30x30 and other odd sizes.  The easy difficulty splits the large puzzles into sections, so you might have to do 4 sections to complete 1 whole puzzle picture.  The hardest difficulty is just one giant grid.

How many puzzles:
Puzzle paintings are organized into Galleries with themes, such as Portraits, Sports of Sorts, Animals, Home Sweet Home, etc.  If forget exactly how many puzzles are in each gallery, maybe about 8-10 or so.  You unlock more galleries as you complete puzzles are get the medals.  You get more medals for solving on higher difficulty.

Help Tools:
If you need help there are some in-game help tools that you can activate, though you might not get a medal for solving that puzzle.

Story:
Yes, a puzzle game with a story!  There is a cute little story scene in the beginning.  And a small one once you complete all the puzzles once on any difficulty.

Graphics:
Cute and colorful.

Sound:
Nice effects like paint splat sounds when you mark a puzzle.  The background music has several tracks that loop continously.  

Interface:
I used a mouse.  No problems.  

Replay value:
Once you get pretty far into the puzzles you unlock Mystery mode.  Where you can try to solve a random puzzle (from one of the galleries) only it does not show you the progress in the little picture and doesn't tell you the title, either.  So you have to do it by logic only, no guessing!  You can choose any difficulty level in Mystery mode.

Achievements!  
All of the achievements are easily doable, just takes some time.  There aren't any super hard achievements (so far).

A Painter is Never Satisfied with his finished product.
The developer listens to the fans and has made updates with new features based on ideas from fans.  It's always nice to see a dev willing to tweek his game if the fans want something.

I can't remember how much it cost but it's well worth it.  And I actually bought my copy, unlike some people who got free review copies.  

That's all I can think of to say.  Just about the perfect puzzle game.  A little story, nice puzzles, lots of options for difficulty.  Oh and there is humor as well.  Some of the painting titles are puns on famous paintings or pop culture references.  If you like logic puzzles, you can't go wrong with this game.

18636187.review:
Полная версия здесь - http://www.vgblogs.ru/2015/10/paint-it-back-mnenie.html

Так вот, переходя к сути. Paint it Back - это сборник тех самых японских кроссвордов (или сканвордов), но под личиной интерактивного развлечения для планшетов и персональных компьютеров. Причём студия Casual Labs на все сто оправдывает своё название: разработчикам в своих пробирках удалось создать настолько затягивающую и прилипчивую игру с понятными правилами, что по мере её прохождения развивается натуральная аддикция. Не исключаю, что продвинутый игрок наверняка сумеет одолеть кампанию за пару-тройку часов, напишет гневный или нейтральный отзыв, и навсегда забудет о ней. Но я буквально попал в плен и могу с равным успехом зависнуть в ней и на десять минут, и на несколько часов к ряду. И самое страшное, что постоянно тянет вернуться, попытать счастья на дополнительных уровнях сложности...

На банальную сюжетную завязку не стоит даже обращать внимание: малютка-привидение натворил дел в художественной галерее, загубил множество полотен и теперь должен исправить случившееся. Об этом вам расскажут в коротеньком вступительном ролике, затем протащат за шкирку через обучение азам, а в итоге оставят наедине с задачей.

Самое главное в любом паззле, конечно, головоломки. А с этим в Paint it Back полный порядок: игрокам предстоит отреставрировать полторы сотни картин, развешанных по тематическим залам. Показательно, что (как и любая хорошая казуалка) игра бывает и максимально дружелюбной к новичку, и мучительно сложной для специалиста. Большую часть произведений искусства разрешают восстанавливать в нескольких режимах. Например, большое полотно на обычной сложности разобьют на кучку маленьких секций - в этом случае вероятность ошибки минимальная, а к вашим услугам полно ключевых точек и пересечений, с которых можно начинать закрашивать квадратики в нужном порядке. На профессиональном уровне, очевидно, придётся порой поломать голову, а в режиме "мастера" на решение одной загадки немудрено потратить час реального времени.

Хотя рано или поздно вы поймаете себя на мысли, что скилл растёт и некоторые нюансы становятся очевидными после первого взгляда - ещё до того момента, когда мозг обработает полученную информацию.

Дисклеймер: ревью-код

18573101.review:
I love these kinds of puzzle games for playing whilst I'm doing other things, and this game has certainly provided a good few hours of puzzle-solving distraction. It's pretty much what it looks like - a logic puzzle game where you 'create' pixel art based on number clues given to you.

[b] Pros [/b]
+ Quirky bright graphics
+ Easy to use interface
+ Decent number of puzzles
+ Sufficient level of challenge and the player chooses which challenge level they'd like for each puzzle
+ Few additional things to aim for over and above just finishing the puzzles, if you want to earn all the achievements

[b] Cons [/b]
- I might be wrong, but I don't think all of the 'master' level puzzles are solvable through logic alone. If true, that's not great - I don't want to be forced to play out a guess in these kinds of puzzles.
*Edit - Although I still don't agree with having puzzles in the game that are unsolvable by traditional methods, I do want to add that the developer is extremely responsive and as a result of mine and others' feedback has added a message in the game that lets you know if a puzzle requires the mark-up mode before you start it. I'm impressed by their response to constructive criticism as too often (in my opinion) devs either don't respond or respond badly it seems. Kudos to the devs on this one.

[b] Would have been nice to have [/b]
Not exactly 'cons', but... While you're solving each puzzle there's a 'painting' in the top left which paints the pixels in colours as you progress. In some cases, this made it obvious where the next squares should go - I hid the painting by using windowed mode and pushing it off the screen, but it would be nice to switch this off. (I didn't spot this option in the settings). Also, and this is really a personal preference, but my favourite logic puzzles are ones with text puzzles to help you solve the grid, so it would have been great to see a few of these thrown in to mix it up a little.

All in all, does what it says on the tin, and if you like grid-based logic puzzles, you'll like this game.

My only gripes would be that the difficulty sometimes seems a bit random and there are some puzzles that as far as I can tell can't logically be deduced. There've been quite a few where I just had to give up after doing half the puzzle because the other half was very ambiguous.

The other issue is kind of opposite to that: some squares are lighter and darker based on the picture being drawn. This, and being able to see the picture being drawn in the top left, lead to situations where it's extremely easy to guess where the squares are meant to go, which kind of ruins the challenge of Picross. I would much prefer if all the squares were straight black and I couldn't see the painting in the top.

In any case, it's well worth the money. Just a few things that kind of ruin the spirit of the game.

18513577.review:
Paint It Back is a great nonogram puzzle game with a painting theme that I am absolutely addicted to (as you can probably tell from my playtime). A nonogram is a puzzle where you are given a grid and each row and column has one or more numbers by it which tells you how many consecutive cells need to be filled in in that row or column. You will need to use logical thinking and information from other rows and columns to figure out which cells are the ones that should be filled in and complete the painting.

It's hard to explain why Paint It Back is so addicting but it is. It is definitely one of those "one more turn" type of games. You will sit down to play it for an hour to wind down and it will be past midnight before you know it. I think the main reason why it is so fun and addicting is that it is a very simple game to play but it also requires a lot of logical thinking to complete the paintings.

Paint It Back offers a lot of bang for your buck. At the time of this review, I had put in over 21 hours and I still have a lot of puzzles left to complete. I estimate that it will take me at least 25 total hours to complete all of the puzzles and that's with me focusing on mainly the normal and pro paintings (the master difficulty puzzles are very time consuming).

If you like puzzle games at all and especially if you like nonograms or similar puzzles like Sudoku you should definitely check out Paint It Back.

Note: I received a free review copy of the game but received no other compensation for this review.

[url=http://www.geekyhobbies.com/paint-it-back-indie-game-review/] Read my full review [/url]

18513507.review: I love it. I love these kind of puzzles, and yay! a new game full of them!

18508149.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Picross. That’s the thing I keep hearing whenever I see games like this come by. These sorts of games are easily spotted, because of the large squares with numbers on the sides, and a picture of what you’re creating in the corner. I remember having played one or two of them back in the day but to be honest I can’t remember what they were like. Time to find out if there may have been a reason for this…

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The story is quite simple and begins with a ghost wandering around in a museum. It finally manages to scare away all of the paintings and now it’s up to you to paint them back. It’s goofy and it sets the tone immediately. It doesn’t take itself seriously and that’s exactly what it should be like. It’s a casual game at heart, as in anyone can pick it up and play. The difficulty is also targeted at a casual audience and since there’s no time limit you can take your time until you have finally figured out how to paint it properly. However, you can also choose to play a more difficult/advanced version of puzzles and these puzzles then consist of multiple blocks merged together to make it look like one big (wide) puzzle.

Gameplay wise it’s relatively simple. Easy to learn, even easy to master, but it does take some brain activity to figure out how to paint the blocks exactly. The game puts a board in front of you and that board can also be seen in the upper left corner, but on a smaller scale. If you paint a block on the big board – by just clicking on it – then you will also see that block get painted on the smaller board in the corner. By clicking a block again you can remove the paint and by right-clicking you can choose to disable a block to prevent you from accidentally painting over it. While I felt this was fairly useless at the beginning it became more important later on when the boards get bigger and more complex.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536135165
Anyway, there are numbers written on the top and left sides of the board and these tell you how to paint the blocks. By looking at the numbers you can figure out how to paint the blocks properly.
So if you have a 10x10 block and on the ninth line (horizontally) is written ‘10’ then you have paint all ten blocks horizontally. It’s not a very good example, but it’s a little hard to explain without actually drawing an example. But just take a look at the screenshots and you’ll see probably understand what I mean.

Once the painting is complete the smaller board will be enlarged to show you the end result. It’s always a pixel art painting (I always appreciate good pixel art) so don’t go and expect a DaVinci painting or anything, although they do get more complex a few hours into the game.
Also, starting from area 3 puzzles become larger and may even consist of several parts. This means that a painting can be divided into, for example, 2, 4 or 6 parts. This doesn’t influence the actual coloring of the blocks but instead of creating just one big painting you’re then painting several parts that ultimately combine into one big painting. You do get to see the entire painting in the corner, by the way, so you always have a clear idea of what the final result will or should look like.

There are multiple areas to play through, 15 in fact, each with their own theme, but I somehow missed how these paintings exactly relate to these worlds. They seem completely random, but I guess with a little thinking you can see the or some sort of relation between them. It seems farfetched, though, but I assume that’s just part of the goofy style and humor.

Overall the game feels very polished. The only thing I think needs improvement is the audio, of which there is just too little variety. With some added tracks (or at least more rotation) it’s actually pretty much perfect in my opinion.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536135007
[h1]Audio & Visuals[/h1]
So, thus far there doesn’t seem to be a whole lot of diversity as far the music is concerned. The first hour or so I heard the same song over and over with every painting I created. Then out of nowhere I finally heard another song. There seem to be more songs but they currently repeat a bit too often, which is an absolute shame, even though the focus is not the music per se. But more variety (as in: more tracks, or more rotation) would definitely help add to the immersion of being (or at least feeling like) a painter.

Visually it’s a beautiful game with a great looking cartoony style. The cinematics (although I wouldn’t really call them that) look fabulous in motion and the boards animate nicely whenever you complete a painting. Other than that there’s not much animation. The pixel art shown in the frames looks great, but sometimes it still looks a bit too simple. I personally thought it would’ve been cool if the pixel art would animate upon completing a puzzle. It would give it just a little more personality, but to be totally honest you can’t say that this game lacks any. It bursts with personality actually.
Anyway, the text is sharp, the use of colors is diverse and the graphics scale nicely: the game makes the screen (not the game itself) less wide or wider based on what is shown. It looks cool, but is a little inconsistent. 
(Please note that I’m playing on a 21:9 monitor and this may therefore not occur on your monitor.)

[h1]Length/Replay Value[/h1]
There are 150 paintings to complete in total. Most of them can be completed in just a couple of minutes so if you do the math then it should take you anywhere between 10-15 hours to complete. And this is just for the normal paintings. If you choose to complete more advanced paintings then you can easily add another dozen hours to that number. Plus, there’s an Endless Mode for even MORE replay value. Oh yes, you get plenty of bang for your buck. Guaranteed!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536135313 
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Okay, so I might not remember the Picross games (maybe due to a lack of interest, or maybe I didn’t have the right age, who knows?) but I [i]will[/i] try to remember Paint It Back this time. It has become a game that anyone can play and have fun with: a relaxing game meant to be played for just a few minutes or a couple of hours. I definitely had fun with it.
There aren’t many games like this available on PC (or more specifically: Steam) and so it might not become insanely popular (yet). But let’s make sure it at least gets the attention it deserves. Buy it and recommend it if you agree!

[h1]Too long, didn’t read[/h1]
Pros:
+ Artistic graphics complement the style of the game
+ Fun, at times challenging, puzzles
+ Anyone can play it; it’s very easy to pick up and learn
+ Extremely relaxing atmosphere

Mixed:
+/- Could benefit from some extra visual effects maybe

Cons:
- Music tracks repeat too often, or there aren’t enough tracks

https://youtu.be/0reZ7geGKMo
[i]Game:[/i] Paint it Back
[i]Genre:[/i] Nonogram Puzzle
[i]Developer:[/i] Casual Labs
[i]Publisher:[/i] Casual Labs
[i][u]Copy supplied by developer[/u][/i]

[b]Paint it Back[/b] is a picross/nonogram puzzle game developed and published by Casual Labs.

[h1]STORY[/h1]
The story is basically non-existent: you are the curator of an art gallery, and, after a ghost has stolen the content of every painting, it is your job to paint them back (get it?) and re-open the exhibition. Since there are no cutscenes other than the initial one, I'm not gonna take this into account.

[h1]GRAPHICS[/h1]
The game adopts a very colorful art-style that well suits both the tone of the different rooms full of paintings and the puzzles that you complete. While the paintings get bigger and more complex the more you paint them, most of them are still very simple and lack detail.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
The game is essentially a digital version of nonogram:  are picture logic puzzles in which cells in a grid must be colored or left blank according to numbers at the side of the grid to reveal a hidden picture. In this puzzle type, the numbers are a form of discrete tomography that measures how many unbroken lines of filled-in squares there are in any given row or column.
I had never played this type of puzzle, and it has easily become my favourite: the constant calculation of numbers and the huge satisfaction of seeing a finished work make this game one of the most relaxing and easier to get games of the year.

[h1]CHALLENGE[/h1]
The game's puzzles get increasingly difficult, but you can always choose the difficulty of each one (for example, for a 50x50 puzzle you can choose Normal to complete small 10x10 areas). They are never impossible to complete, and usually waiting a couple of minutes to clear your head up helps.

[h1]SOUND[/h1]
The soundtrack to the game is quirky and relaxing, making this game one to be picked up when you want to chill for 5 or 10 minutes.

[h1]REPLAYABILITY[/h1]
The game features a total of 150 paintings to complete and 20 Steam achievements to unlock, giving you more thane enough content for its cheap price.

Overall, both fans and non-fans of puzzle games (especially nonogram/picross) will enjoy this game thanks to its simplicity, challenge, huge satisfaction and relaxing soundtrack.

18472730.review:
[h1]A very nice addition to the puzzle genre with a sweet and fun cartoonish look.
The pixel art in the game get's better and better with every level.[/h1]

[b]Developer: Casual Labs
Publisher: Casual Labs
Release Date: October 14th, 2015[/b]

[i]Paint it Back[/i] is on the trail of [i]Sudoku[/i] which I guess everyone of us has played at least once so far. It’s a really good and fun game that you can pick up whenever you feel like it.
It started out on iOS and is now here on Steam.

[h1]Story[/h1]
A ghost appeared and literally spooked the paintings away.
So it’s now your job to … [i]Paint it back[/i].

Seriously that’s pretty much it and there’s no need for a fancy storyline.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
If you’ve played Sudoku then the game’s pretty much self explanatory and in case you haven’t well the tutorial does one fine job explaining it.
Let’s get into it. You start of by facing a blank 5x5 field and you have to paint the right squares while leaving others blank. Later on in the game you’ll have to repaint bigger like 16x20.
The game even tells you not to guess but to think. Sure you could guess your way through the early levels and the smaller painting but good luck with that for the bigger ones.

Your only tool is a brush with black paint. You don’t have to worry about choosing the right color for the right square. All you have to do is to paint the right ones. The other [i]tool[/i] you have is the right click. If you right click a square you’ll cross it out so you know that you have it blank.
The game, just like sudoku, gives you some hints so you know where to start and which squares to paint.
On the outside of the field of your painting you see certain numbers. Let’s say the upper left row starts, vertically, with a 4. That means that you have to paint 4 squares in this row and so on.
Some fields have more than one number on the outside. The first number or in this case the outer number’s the same as before and tells you how many squares you have to paint. The second number however tells you that you have to leave some squares blank and then start painting again. Let me demonstrate on a 5x5 field.
Let’s say the upper left, vertically, row starts with a 2 and the next number is a 2 as well.
That would mean that you have to paint two squares, leave one open, and then paint again two.
So you see you get the hang of it pretty quickly.

The game does require a fair amount of brain power though. The beauty of it is that, just as the developers name implies, it’s really a casual game that you can pick up whenever you want.
You can even save your progress in your current painting and come back later to it to finish it.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The game itself has a cartoonish look to it and is quite fitting. The paintings however look great.
The pixel art in the game’s pretty fun, good looking and for me easily the best part of the game.
The early painting might not look the best but they’ll look better and better in the higher levels and way more complex.
Overall it’s a fairly nice and sweet looking game and the whole cartoonish art style was a good choice.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The music just fits and manages to stay in the background while also maintaining presence.
It’s not too subtle but at the same time not too intrusive.
I mean at the end of the day you’ll find yourself paying attention to the music and it will probably hinder you a bit but it’s not too bad.
The tracks used however are quite short which I personally actually like since the level that you’re stuck on won’t get too dull too fast.

[h1]What else can I say?[/h1]
I have been lucky enough to get a Review Key for [i]Paint it Back[/i] in order to write a blunt and honest to God Review. Just as usual.

It is what it is. It’s a nice game for every now and then when you feel like you need something for your brain. Overall it works pretty good and I haven’t had any problems whatsoever.
It’s hard though. Well hard as in some levels are truly complex and require a fair amount of time and you can’t just rush through all of the levels. At the end of the day you’ll probably get a fair amount of gametime out of it if you don’t get too frustrated later on.

The perfect game for every puzzle lover. Especially for people that just need their fix every now and then.

[i]No drama, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/justreviews]Just Reviews.[/url][/i]

- Neku

18472143.review:
I have been a fan of the Picross puzzle games for almost a decade now, having completed all the Nintendo-produced titles on the DS and 3DS and even going back and playing Mario's Picross through the 3DS's Virtual Console. I love the simplicity of the format and how they can, at times, seem impossible to complete until you find that one tiny, little detail you missed and the rest of the picture comes into play.

Paint it Back is missing a couple of the smaller details that make those Nintendo games special but it includes a ton of puzzles, has much bigger puzzles than any of the Nintendo titles, and presents all of them with a great amount of polish, from snappy menus to configurable control schemes to solid performance. This is a really freaking good Picross game on the PC. If you like Picross games then that should really be enough to convince you. If you want more detail, I have lists.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The game runs well on Windows 7, 8 and 10, with no noticeable load times or crashes (so far).
    [*]It works with multiple controllers right out of the gate, including the Xbox One pad, which is how I played most of the time.
    [*]You can switch between a mouse/keyboard combo and a controller at will, even mid-puzzle, and it only takes the game a second to figure out what you're using.
    [*]It's very challenging in spots, even more so than the hardest puzzles in Picross DS. Some of the sets are massive, going past 30x30 in size. This is where it's great to have a big screen. My PC is connected to my 40" TV and it was so nice to play wider puzzles that took up the length of my screen, all while lying on my couch.
    [*]The bigger puzzles can be broken down into bite-sized pieces, making them easier to digest. Instead of doing a 20x20 puzzle, for instance, you can do four 5x5 ones. You get a different amount of ribbons (the game's way to measure progress) based on whether you tackle the whole thing at once or in parts.
    [*]There's enough content to last over 20 hours, at the very least, and a good variety of difficulties from easy to moderately challenging to bang-your-head-against-the-wall hard puzzles, all of which you can save and come back to later if you get too burnt out.
    [*]Columns and rows highlight to help you navigate, which doesn't really matter until you get to the latter puzzles, going past 25x25 or so, but when you do it's super helpful.
    [*]It's a small download and doesn't require a ton of resources so you can play on a laptop without much of a challenge. I found it just as fun to use the arrows and the z/x button combo as the controller.
    [*]it's Picross on your PC. That, in and of itself, is an amazing thing. Even if the game wasn't built well I'd still be happy. Fortunately enough, it is really polished.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]There's no mode or option that you can toggle that'll mark when you make a mistake (at least that I could find). Meaning that if you screw up with a fill instead of an X or vice versa, you won't know it until later when things don't add up. Most of the time I didn't mind this, since you're filling in tons of squares and a simple slip of the thumb might happen, but the option, perhaps in a different mode, would have been welcome.
    [*]For better or worse, not all the achievements have detailed explanations.
    [*]I would have liked more of the wide puzzles and less of the tall ones, since my TV is widescreen, as most monitors are, and it fits better.
    [*]The music gets incredibly repetitive after a couple hours.
[/list]
